bestBHT.bht: Witness the Son of man's authority and power to forgive sins on earth. Jesus reveals this forgiving power in the presence of his followers, assuring them that he possesses the right and ability to forgive sins in the here and now. By focusing on the forgiveness of sins, Jesus demonstrates his authority to forgive without delay, reaching beyond the realm of what is physically seen. He establishes his dominion to forgive sins in the present, rather than waiting for the day of judgment.

Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: But that ye may know that the Son of man hath power on earth to forgive sins—that forgiving power dwells in the Person of this Man."
The forgiving power is exercised by Him while on this earth and going out and in with you."
(he saith to the sick of the palsy).
Marvin Vincent: Power [εξουσιαν] ; or better, authority, as Rev., in margin.
The word is derived from exesti, it is permitted or lawful.
Authority or right is the dominant meaning in the New Testament.
Archibald T. Robertson: Jesus chose the harder first, the forgiveness which they could not see.
He really had the authority and power to forgive sins.
He has the right and power here on earth to forgive sins, here and now without waiting for the day of judgment.
John Gill: His humbling himself in human nature did not strip him of his perfections, power, and prerogative as God."
If he had power on earth to forgive sin, there can be no room to doubt of it now he is in heaven.
Turning to, and addressing him in the following words, with great majesty, authority, and power.

bhtAttempts.bht: Know that the Son of man has the authority and power to forgive sins here and now on earth, which is demonstrated by the forgiving power that resides in Him. This forgiving authority is exercised by Him while He walks on this earth among His followers. Jesus intentionally chose to showcase the more challenging task first - forgiving sins which could not be physically seen. Not only does He possess the right and power to forgive sins, but He exercises this authority in the present moment, without waiting for the day of judgment.

That you may know that the Son of man has the authority and power on earth to forgive sins, Jesus showcases his ability to forgive sins during his time on earth. This forgiving power is not just a future promise, but a present reality. He deliberately chooses to address the forgiveness of sins first, demonstrating that he possesses the right and ability to forgive sins without delay. Through this act, Jesus establishes his authority and power to forgive sins here and now, without waiting for the day of judgment.

That you may see the authority and power of the Son of man to forgive sins on earth, Jesus demonstrates his ability to forgive sins in the present moment. He intentionally addresses the forgiveness of sins first, emphasizing that he truly possesses the right and power to forgive sins, here and now. This forgiveness is not limited to some future event but is accessible in the present moment, without delay. Through this act, Jesus establishes his authority to forgive sins without waiting for the day of judgment.

Witness the Son of man's authority and power to forgive sins on earth. Jesus reveals this forgiving power in the presence of his followers, assuring them that he possesses the right and ability to forgive sins in the here and now. By focusing on the forgiveness of sins, Jesus demonstrates his authority to forgive without delay, reaching beyond the realm of what is physically seen. He establishes his dominion to forgive sins in the present, rather than waiting for the day of judgment.

Jesus wants to show that he has the authority and power to forgive sins here on earth, a power that resides in him as a man. This forgiving power is not just a future promise, but something that is exercised by him in the present, as he moves among his followers. By focusing on forgiveness, Jesus demonstrates his rightful authority to forgive sins without delay, without waiting for the day of judgment. His ability to forgive sins is not diminished by his human nature, but is an intrinsic part of his divine character.
